Mr. President, Members of the

I deeply appreciate the honour of being invited to take part in
your program this evening.

Also, though feeling myself in no wise deserving of the very kind
introduction of Dr. Noland ----, I am thankful to say that I have something new to
present to you that is deserving of your consideration and on a subject
that cannot fail to be of interest to so representative a groupebody of the
medical profession in the State which can boast a Nott and a Gorgas!

For the past nine years I have been a small part of a great
work--an inquiry into the early history of yellow fever. The method,
findings and conclusions of this inquiry I shall now endeavor to briefly outline to you.
See p. 21.

It would seem natural in investigating the history of any
disease to begin by collecting accounts of its occurrence, beginning with
the earliest procurable records, and from them to finally deduce our gen-
eral principles--the conditions under which and only under which, it can
occur: the epidemiology of the disease.

A different, almost a reversed, method was followed in this
instance: This because certain principles in the epidemiology of yellow
fever are established and definitely known, while the early reports of
its occurrence (and non-occurrence) are frequently not only only misleading
but erroneous. Therefore by beginning our inquiry with a statement of the
finally established principles in the epidemiology of yellow fever (the con-
ditions under which, and only under which, yellow fever can occur) the truth or
error of the historical and archaeological evidence examined can be properly
evaluated. For instance:

We learn from epidemiological data that in tropical America
Mexico and Central America an altitude of somewhat over 4,000 ft has proven
“non-infectible territory” for yellow fever (temperature too low for infes-
tation by the insect vector). By this we know that the epidemic among the
Aztecs in the year 1 Rabbit (1454), which has been interpreted as showing an
epidemic of yellow fever, could not have been this disease. The action of
the Nahuatl picture for this year took place on the Mexican plateau, about
8,000 ft. above sea-level. There yellow fever is out of the question.

Cocolitzle. Similarly we can judge concerning what is the most
mfamous and often-quoted passage cited in evidence of the presence of yellow
fever in the New World priot to the Spanish Conquest, the “Cocolitzle” of
Herrera. Herrera y Tordesillos, official historiographer to Philip ii of
Spain, states that before the coming of the Spaniards, the “tierra caliente”
(hot low country) around Vera Cruz was rendered so unhealthy a disease, or

diseases, called “Cocolistle” that it was periodically depopulated. That,
whenever this occurred, Montezuma collected a unit of 8,000 families from
a healthy part of his kingdom and repopulated it, giving the new settlers
houses and land and rendering them free from tribute for many years.
Now we know, from the epidemiology of this disease.

(a) That yellow fever would not depopulate such a large, thickly
settled area as the Spaniards found on landing at Vera Cruz. Were yellow
fever endemic there, the inhabitants would contract the disease in infancy
(with only a small increase in infant mortality) and (one attack conferring
immunity) the adult native population would not be affected by it.

(b) Moreover, one cannot conceive of a more effective way of
keeping up yellow fever than that cited as being used by Montezuma to
counteract its ill effects--the introduction of large bodies of susceptible
(non-immune) people. Such and introduction would, have inevitably, have always
created an epidemic.

There is also considerable historical evidence against the fact
that this hot, low country was unhealthy before the arrival of the Spaniards.
The epidemiological argument, however, would seem sufficient (conclusive)
without it.

I would here state, parenthetically, that since this inquiry into
the early history of yellow fever was, naturally, not confined to the
Americas, it seemed inadvisable to use our venacular form (Stegomyia) for the name of the
insect vector (in nature) *. This, because while it is the only species of this sub-
genus found in the Americas, there are a number of Aëdes (Stegomyia) species
in the Old World. It was decided then to return to the name given it by
Linnaes himself Linnaous himself: Aedes (Stegomyia) aegypti, this name
being definitive everywhere)
Place of Origin.

Naturally, one of the most important questions to be
determined in the early history of yellow fever was the question of its place
of origin. And this was a matter of more than academic interest. The
Rockefeller Foundation (in consultation with Gorgas and Father) had already
undertaken[unclear] decided on (and started) its great under-
taking for the elimination of yellow fever from the world and it was felt
the place of origin might present difficulties in such a campaign not to be f
found in places to which the disease had been carried later: (a) greater
difficulty of diagnosis, the natives having the disease more mildly after
having been subject to it for many generations: (b) the possibility of other
vectors, carriers than the known vector, the Aedes (Steg.) aegypti mosquito
and (c) even the possibility of a resevoir host (as is the wild game of Africa
for se sleeping sickness.

Now from our established epidemiological data we derive the pos-
tulate that “for the naturally continued existence of y. f. in any place
there are necessary three factors coexistent at that place (1) the causative
organism (2) functionally active A. (Steg.) aegypti mosquitoes (3) men sus-
ceptible to the infection, the mosquitoes having access to both of the other
two.” (Carter)

Now for the continued existence of these three factors certain
certain
p.4
conditions are necessary: (a) a minimal temperature sufficiently warm
high for the functional activity of (the aegypti insect vector) and for the development
of the causative organism in the mosquito. (b) A sufficiently supply of
susceptible people to keep up this disease, of which one attack so soon
produces immunity, either by (1) immigration (b) birth rate (another form
of immigration) (Dutroulau)? or (c) intercommunication between a number of
small units of population, none sufficiently large to keep it up alone, but
all together forming a “regional focus.”
